elements.content: A semi-rigid organic linker, namely, 3,3′,5,5′-tetra­kis­(4-(α-carboxy)­meth­oxy­phenyl)-2,2′,6,6′-tetra­methoxy-1,1′-biphenyl (H 4 L), was designed and synthesized to access metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). While the ortho-methoxy substituents in the biphenyl core of H 4 L were surmised to twist the aromatic planes and impart porosity to the resultant MOFs, the (α-car­boxy)­meth­oxy­phenyl moieties at the periphery were envisaged to enable requisite flexibility for metal–ligand coordination polymerization. The reactions of H 4 L with Cd, Mn, and Zn salts indeed yielded MOFs, i.e., Cd-L, Mn-L, Zn-Lsqc, and Zn-Ldia, with interesting structural features and unusual inorganic SBUs. In particular, the reaction of H 4 L with ZnI2 in DMF at 90 °C over 2 days led to concomitant formation of a pair of compositionally distinct Zn-MOFs, i.e., Zn-Ldia and Zn-Lsqc, each of which could be accessed exclusively by controlling the reaction conditions. The diversity observed in the structures of MOFs formed with the linker H 4 L with a limited number of metal ions sufficiently emphasizes the importance of the attributes of the linker in the formation of 3D MOFs; the latter are desirable from the stability and exfoliation points of view when the MOFs are explored for applications such as gas storage, catalysis, etc. In corroboration of our previous results, it emerges that the flexibility that is built into the structure of the organic linker, both at the central core and at the periphery, leads to concomitant formation of compositionally distinct MOFs in addition to diverse SBUs and disparate framework topologies.
elements.clean_text: A semi-rigid organic linker, namely, 3,3',5,5'-tetrakis(4-(α-carboxy)methoxyphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetramethoxy-1,1'-biphenyl (H  4  L), was designed and synthesized to access metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). While the ortho-methoxy substituents in the biphenyl core of H  4  L were surmised to twist the aromatic planes and impart porosity to the resultant MOFs, the (α-carboxy)methoxyphenyl moieties at the periphery were envisaged to enable requisite flexibility for metal-ligand coordination polymerization. The reactions of H  4  L with Cd, Mn, and Zn salts indeed yielded MOFs, i.e., Cd-L, Mn-L, Zn-Lsqc, and Zn-Ldia, with interesting structural features and unusual inorganic SBUs. In particular, the reaction of H  4  L with ZnI2 in DMF at 90 °C over 2 days led to concomitant formation of a pair of compositionally distinct Zn-MOFs, i.e., Zn-Ldia and Zn-Lsqc, each of which could be accessed exclusively by controlling the reaction conditions. The diversity observed in the structures of MOFs formed with the linker H  4  L with a limited number of metal ions sufficiently emphasizes the importance of the attributes of the linker in the formation of 3D MOFs; the latter are desirable from the stability and exfoliation points of view when the MOFs are explored for applications such as gas storage, catalysis, etc. In corroboration of our previous results, it emerges that the flexibility that is built into the structure of the organic linker, both at the central core and at the periphery, leads to concomitant formation of compositionally distinct MOFs in addition to diverse SBUs and disparate framework topologies.

elements.content: Structural attributes of a biaryl-tetraacid, namely, a semi-rigid structure with peripheral conformational flexibility and variable coordination modes, play a crucial role in determining the topologies of MOFs. It is shown that the flexibility that is built into the structure of the organic linker, both at the central core and at the periphery, leads to concomitant formation of compositionally distinct MOFs in addition to diverse SBUs and disparate framework topologies.
elements.clean_text: Structural attributes of a biaryl-tetraacid, namely, a semi-rigid structure with peripheral conformational flexibility and variable coordination modes, play a crucial role in determining the topologies of MOFs. It is shown that the flexibility that is built into the structure of the organic linker, both at the central core and at the periphery, leads to concomitant formation of compositionally distinct MOFs in addition to diverse SBUs and disparate framework topologies.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are exotic porous materials that permit diverse applications such as gas storage, molecular sieving, sensing, magnetism, catalysis, bioimaging, drug delivery, etc. Synthesis of MOFs with predefined framework structures remains still a challenge, as the reactions to access them depend on a variety of parameters, which include metal–linker ratio, pH, solvent employed, temperature, coordination number and geometry of the metal ion, nature of the counterion used, additive, etc. It is needless to say that the structural attributes of an organic linker play a crucial role in determining the structures as well as topologies of the derived frameworks due to variable coordination modes, conformational flexibility, and presence of different secondary functional groups. The synthesis/crystallization process by which the MOFs are accessed is sensitive to different reaction parameters, and often results in the occurrence of unusual secondary building units (SBUs). The latter in turn lead to formation of interesting and varied network structures. Consequently, formation of two or more different metal–organic frameworks from the same synthesis/crystallization pot with intriguing structure types is not rare, which indeed subverts the anticipated framework structures based on connectivity dispositions of the linker and coordination preferences of the metal ions. In principle, one may access coordination polymers with the same framework chemical formula, but different structures or those that differ in terms of both chemical formula as well as structural attributes. The former have been popularly termed “supramolecular isomers”, while those differing in chemical formulas have been termed “structural isomers”. The literature reveals abundant examples of solvent-, template-, counterion-, additive-, and temperature-dependent formation of isomeric coordination polymers. MOFs being materials whose structures and chemical functionalities can be tuned in a bottom-up approach through the linkers modifications, the structure–property relationships help in deciphering subtle factors that are important for their functional properties. At the same time, understanding factors that control when and how different MOFs are formed from the same components and under identical reaction conditions is central to the development of MOFs in a rational way.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are exotic porous materials that permit diverse applications such as gas storage, molecular sieving, sensing, magnetism, catalysis, bioimaging, drug delivery, etc. Synthesis of MOFs with predefined framework structures remains still a challenge, as the reactions to access them depend on a variety of parameters, which include metal-linker ratio, pH, solvent employed, temperature, coordination number and geometry of the metal ion, nature of the counterion used, additive, etc. It is needless to say that the structural attributes of an organic linker play a crucial role in determining the structures as well as topologies of the derived frameworks due to variable coordination modes, conformational flexibility, and presence of different secondary functional groups. The synthesis/crystallization process by which the MOFs are accessed is sensitive to different reaction parameters, and often results in the occurrence of unusual secondary building units (SBUs). The latter in turn lead to formation of interesting and varied network structures. Consequently, formation of two or more different metal-organic frameworks from the same synthesis/crystallization pot with intriguing structure types is not rare, which indeed subverts the anticipated framework structures based on connectivity dispositions of the linker and coordination preferences of the metal ions. In principle, one may access coordination polymers with the same framework chemical formula, but different structures or those that differ in terms of both chemical formula as well as structural attributes. The former have been popularly termed "supramolecular isomers", while those differing in chemical formulas have been termed "structural isomers". The literature reveals abundant examples of solvent-, template-, counterion-, additive-, and temperature-dependent formation of isomeric coordination polymers. MOFs being materials whose structures and chemical functionalities can be tuned in a bottom-up approach through the linkers modifications, the structure-property relationships help in deciphering subtle factors that are important for their functional properties. At the same time, understanding factors that control when and how different MOFs are formed from the same components and under identical reaction conditions is central to the development of MOFs in a rational way.

elements.content: We recently showed that the tetrapyridyl-functionalized rigid tetratopic ligand, i.e., 2,2′,6,6′-tetra­meth­oxy-3,3′,5,5′-tetra­pyridyl­biphenyl, shows flexible coordination behavior to lend itself as 3- as well as 4-connecting linker, depending on the conditions, to yield porous coordination polymers of different topologies. We reasoned that the central 2,2′,6,6′-tetra­meth­oxy­biphenyl scaffold provides the ligand with enough torsional flexibility to adapt itself to the geometric requirements of the metal ion(s) and the counterion(s) in the construction of coordination polymers. In the present investigation, we have modified the same linker to include an acetic acid functionality at the periphery to increase coordination flexibility, i.e., 3,3′,5,5′-tetra­kis­(4-(α-car­boxy)­meth­oxy­phenyl)-2,2′,6,6′-tetra­meth­oxy-1,1′-biphenyl (H 4 L), and sought to explore how the increased flexibility manifests in the structures of the MOFs derived from such a linker. We have recently shown that increased peripheral flexibility in a trigonal triacid linker leads to concomitant formation of two different compositionally distinct MOFs, which could be isolated independently by variation of temperature. This finding was also a motivation to investigate metal-assisted self-assembly of the tetraacid linker H 4 L with different metal ions. Indeed, the reaction of H 4 L with cadmium, manganese, and zinc salts led to four porous MOFs of different topologies. The reaction of ZnI2 with H 4 L yielded two distinct MOFs concomitantly, and each of these could be engineered exclusively by controlling experimental variables such as temperature and additive. Herein, we report structural features of the MOFs accessed with H 4 L and the results of investigations on concomitant formation of compositionally distinct MOFs.

We reasoned that the central 2,2',6,6'-tetramethoxybiphenyl scaffold provides the ligand with enough torsional flexibility to adapt itself to the geometric requirements of the metal ion(s) and the counterion(s) in the construction of coordination polymers. In the present investigation, we have modified the same linker to include an acetic acid functionality at the periphery to increase coordination flexibility, i.e., 3,3',5,5'-tetrakis(4-(α-carboxy)methoxyphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetramethoxy-1,1'-biphenyl (H  4  L), and sought to explore how the increased flexibility manifests in the structures of the MOFs derived from such a linker. elements.content: The organic linker H 4 L was synthesized starting from 3,3′,5,5′-tetra­iodo-2,2′,6,6′-tetra­meth­oxy­biphenyl by following the procedure reported previously from our laboratory. The tetra­iodo­biaryl was subjected to Suzuki coupling with 4-(tert-but­yl­di­meth­yl­silyl­oxy)­phenyl­boronic acid, and the resultant product was subsequently desilylated to get hold of the tetraphenol, as shown in the . The reaction of tetraphenol with ethyl bromoacetate in the presence of K2CO3 led to the corresponding tetraester, i.e., 3,3′,5,5′-tetra­kis­(4-(α-carbo­ethoxy)­meth­oxyphenyl)-2,2′,6,6′-tetra­meth­oxy-1,1′-biphenyl. Base-catalyzed hydrolysis of the tetraester yielded the target tetraacid linker H 4 L.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis of Flexible Organic Linker H4L 

The organic linker H  4  L was synthesized starting from 3,3',5,5'-tetraiodo-2,2',6,6'-tetramethoxybiphenyl by following the procedure reported previously from our laboratory. The tetraiodobiaryl was subjected to Suzuki coupling with 4-(tert-butyldimethylsilyloxy)phenylboronic acid, and the resultant product was subsequently desilylated to get hold of the tetraphenol, as shown in the . The reaction of tetraphenol with ethyl bromoacetate in the presence of K2CO3 led to the corresponding tetraester, i.e., 3,3',5,5'-tetrakis(4-(α-carboethoxy)methoxyphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetramethoxy-1,1'-biphenyl. Base-catalyzed hydrolysis of the tetraester yielded the target tetraacid linker H  4  L.

elements.content: Four different MOFs, referred to as Cd-L, Mn-L, Zn-Lsqc, and Zn-Ldia, were obtained from solvothermal reactions of the tetraacid H 4 L with CdCl2, MnCl2, and ZnI2, respectively, in DMF. The MOF Cd-L was obtained from the reaction of H 4 L with CdCl2 at 115 °C for 3 days, while Mn-L was obtained via the reaction of H 4 L with CdCl2 at 120 °C for 2 days. The reaction of H 4 L with ZnI2 in DMF at 90 °C over a period of 2 days led to formation of two different plate- and block-shaped crystals, as revealed from visual inspection under a microscope (cf. ). When the reaction of H 4 L with ZnI2 in DMF was carried out at 110 °C, block-shaped crystals (Zn-Ldia) were found to be formed exclusively. In a similar manner, when the reaction was carried out in the presence of an equivalent amount of 4,4′-bipyridine at 90 °C, plate-shaped crystals (Zn-Lsqc) were found to be formed exclusively. This was indeed surprising, as the motivation behind introducing 4,4′-bipyridine into the reaction mixture was to access MOFs based on mixed ligands. Clearly, the additive influences the course of MOF synthesis without itself being not involved in the construction of coordination polymer. Details of the MOFs obtained with H 4 L along with the reaction conditions for their syntheses, contents of the asymmetric units, void volumes, and the topologies deduced by incisive analysis of the X-ray determined structures are collated in . The crystal data for all the MOFs are given in . In the following are described structural aspects for each of the MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Single Crystal X-ray Structure Determinations of MOFs

Four different MOFs, referred to as Cd-L, Mn-L, Zn-Lsqc, and Zn-Ldia, were obtained from solvothermal reactions of the tetraacid H  4  L with CdCl2, MnCl2, and ZnI2, respectively, in DMF. The MOF Cd-L was obtained from the reaction of H  4  L with CdCl2 at 115 °C for 3 days, while Mn-L was obtained via the reaction of H  4  L with CdCl2 at 120 °C for 2 days. The reaction of H  4  L with ZnI2 in DMF at 90 °C over a period of 2 days led to formation of two different plate- and block-shaped crystals, as revealed from visual inspection under a microscope (cf. ). When the reaction of H  4  L with ZnI2 in DMF was carried out at 110 °C, block-shaped crystals (Zn-Ldia) were found to be formed exclusively. In a similar manner, when the reaction was carried out in the presence of an equivalent amount of 4,4'-bipyridine at 90 °C, plate-shaped crystals (Zn-Lsqc) were found to be formed exclusively. This was indeed surprising, as the motivation behind introducing 4,4'-bipyridine into the reaction mixture was to access MOFs based on mixed ligands. Clearly, the additive influences the course of MOF synthesis without itself being not involved in the construction of coordination polymer. Details of the MOFs obtained with H  4  L along with the reaction conditions for their syntheses, contents of the asymmetric units, void volumes, and the topologies deduced by incisive analysis of the X-ray determined structures are collated in . The crystal data for all the MOFs are given in . In the following are described structural aspects for each of the MOFs.

Treatment of H 4 L with CdCl2 in DMF at 115° for 3 days led to block-shaped crystals. Single crystal X-ray structure determination showed that one obtains a MOF, which crystallizes in the tetragonal space group F222. The asymmetric unit of Cd-L contains one linker L and three crystallographically independent Cd­(II) ions with occupancies of 0.5, 0.5, and 1 for Cd1, Cd2, and Cd3, respectively. In the crystal structure, one observes that the Cd­(II) ions are arranged in a zigzag fashion, forming 1D zigzag chains down the a-axis (b).

Cd-L 

Treatment of H  4  L with CdCl2 in DMF at 115° for 3 days led to block-shaped crystals. Single crystal X-ray structure determination showed that one obtains a MOF, which crystallizes in the tetragonal space group F222. The asymmetric unit of Cd-L contains one linker L and three crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions with occupancies of 0.5, 0.5, and 1 for Cd1, Cd2, and Cd3, respectively. In the crystal structure, one observes that the Cd(II) ions are arranged in a zigzag fashion, forming 1D zigzag chains down the a-axis (b).

elements.content: (a) Crystal packing of Cd-L down a-axis. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. (b) 1D metal-carboxylate chain of Cd-L containing three crystallographically different Cd­(II) ions; note the penta- and octahedral coordination modes of Cd­(II) ions. (c) Simplified representation of the noninterpenetrated net of Cd-L as revealed from TOPOS analysis (metal ion in blue and linker in gray).

elements.content: The distances between the consecutive metal ions are d Cd1–Cd3 = 4.11 Å and d Cd2–Cd3 = 3.36 Å. The metal ions are found to exhibit low coordination numbers in this MOF. The metal ions Cd1 and Cd2 are octahedrally coordinated by two chelated and two monocoordinated carboxylates in each case. The Cd3 ions exhibit distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry with one of the positions occupied by a water molecule; the pentacoordinated Cd­(II) ion is very unusual. As shown in a, the framework is biporous, and contains channels of 15.6 × 6.05 Å and 9.03 × 6.47 Å dimensions down the a-axis. The framework is noninterpenetrated with a solvent-accessible volume of 43.3%. As expected, the organic linker L serves as a pair of 3-connecting units to construct the network. Topological analysis of the MOF, i.e., Cd-L, by the TOPOS software reveals that the framework structure is a 3,6-connecting 3D net with an unprecedented topology (c).

elements.content: Colorless crystals of Mn-L were obtained when H 4 L was reacted with MnCl2 in DMF at 120 °C for 2 days. The crystals were found to belong to P1̅ space group with the asymmetric unit containing one linker, two Mn­(II) ions with 1 and 0.5 occupancies, two dimethylammonium ions, one water molecule coordinated to the metal ion, and two molecules of DMF (cf. ). The crystal packing analysis shows that the clusters of three Mn­(II) ionscoordinated by eight carboxylate groups corresponding to eight different linker molecules and two water moleculesserve as 8-connecting SBUs with the linker L behaving as a pair of 3-connecting units to generate a 3D framework (cf. ). Clearly, the framework is anionic with the dimethylammonium ion, derived from N,N-dimethylformamide, serving to balance the negative charge of the framework. The metal ions in the cluster are found to be arranged linearly with a typical Mn1–Mn2 distance of 3.74 Å. As shown in the c, all the three Mn­(II) ions in the cluster are octahedrally coordinated by the carboxylate groups. Overall, the network is noninterpenetrated with the voids propagating down a- and b-axes (a,b). PLATON analysis reveals that the solvent-accessible volume in the network structure is ca. 50%. Analysis of the framework topology of Mn-L by TOPOS program revealed that the combination of 8-connecting trimetallic node and the ligand, which can be considered as a pair of 3-connecting node, leads to an sqc-495 type network (d).

elements.content: The reaction of tetraacid H 4 L with ZnI2 in DMF at 90 °C for 2 days led to concomitant formation of plate-like crystals (Zn-Lsqc) and block-shaped crystals (Zn-Ldia) in ca. 3:7 ratio (). While the crystals of Zn-Lsqc were found to crystallize in the triclinic crystal system with space group P1̅, those of Zn-Ldia were found to crystallize in the orthorhombic space group F222. From temperature-dependent synthesis of the Zn-MOF, it was established that the crystals Zn-Ldia form exclusively when the reaction is carried out at 110 °C, keeping all other experimental conditions unaltered. In the same vein, the crystals of only Zn-Lsqc were found to be formed when the reaction of H 4 L with ZnI2 was carried out in the presence of an equivalent amount of 4,4′-bipyridine in DMF at 90 °C for 2 days. It is noteworthy that 4,4′-bipyridine is not involved in the construction of the framework, but serves merely as a template leading to the noninterpenetrated open framework structure of Zn-Lsqc exclusively.
elements.clean_text:
Zn-Lsqc and Zn-Ldia 

The reaction of tetraacid H  4  L with ZnI2 in DMF at 90 °C for 2 days led to concomitant formation of plate-like crystals (Zn-Lsqc) and block-shaped crystals (Zn-Ldia) in ca. 3:7 ratio (). While the crystals of Zn-Lsqc were found to crystallize in the triclinic crystal system with space group P1̅, those of Zn-Ldia were found to crystallize in the orthorhombic space group F222. From temperature-dependent synthesis of the Zn-MOF, it was established that the crystals Zn-Ldia form exclusively when the reaction is carried out at 110 °C, keeping all other experimental conditions unaltered. In the same vein, the crystals of only Zn-Lsqc were found to be formed when the reaction of H  4  L with ZnI2 was carried out in the presence of an equivalent amount of 4,4'-bipyridine in DMF at 90 °C for 2 days. It is noteworthy that 4,4'-bipyridine is not involved in the construction of the framework, but serves merely as a template leading to the noninterpenetrated open framework structure of Zn-Lsqc exclusively.

elements.content: Analysis of the single crystal data reveals that Zn-Lsqc is isostructural to Mn-L, and contains trimeric linear Zn­(II) clusters that are coordinated by eight carboxylate groups, whereby the metal cluster is rendered an 8-connecting node. However, a slight difference is noteworthy in terms of the coordination modes of the metal ions in the cluster. Unlike in Mn-L, the central metal ion is octahedral in nature in the case of Zn-Lsqc, while the terminal ions display a tetrahedral mode of coordination (c). The distance between two consecutive metal ions is 3.66 Å. As in the case of Mn-L, one observes channels down a- and b-axes (a,b). The solvent-accessible volume in the network structure is ca. 52% as calculated by PLATON. The MOF is made up of noninterpenetrated 3,8-connecting sqc-495 network as that found in the case of Mn-L MOF (d).

elements.content: In contrast, the framework of the MOF Zn-Ldia contains discrete zinc ions that make up the nodes (cf. b). The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Zn­(II) ions with an occupancy of 0.5 each and one ligand. Both metal ions in the asymmetric unit exhibit distorted octahedral geometry, being chelated by two carboxylate groups and monocoordinated by two other carboxylate groups. Overall, the metal ions act as tetrahedral nodes with very similar dispositions. Clearly, the combination of the tetrahedral nodes with the D 2d -symmetric linkers L leads to a diamondoid network, which is anionic; two dimethylammonium cations are expected to be present in the lattice to compensate for the charge (cf. c). Unlike other cases, this particular MOF is 4-fold interpenetrated (d). In spite of the high degree of interpenetration, the solvent-accessible volume of Zn-Ldia is ca. 45.5%, which is similar to other noninterpenetrated MOFs.

elements.content: The main objective of this investigation was to increase the coordination flexibility of the tetraacid linker and explore the accessibility of porous MOFs. Given that the carboxylate functionalities exhibit variable coordination modes, our goals were to access MOFs of the flexible H 4 L linker with different metal ions, and investigate the possibility of formation of MOFs that are isomeric or compositionally distinct, as in our earlier study. As evident from foregoing descriptions, we were successful in obtaining four different MOFs of the 4-connecting linker H 4 L. The four MOFs are Cd-MOF, Mn-MOF, and two concomitant Zn-MOFs with varying compositions of the linker and Zn2+ ions. Structure determinations of the otherwise limited number of MOFs demonstrate the fact that the unique D 2d -symmetry extant to the H 4 L linker allows, in first place, access to MOFs with high solvent-accessible volumes, which vary in the range of 43–52%. Clearly, the linker topology is decisive in controlling the porosity.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Features of the MOFs and Concomitant Formation of Compositionally Distinct MOFs

The main objective of this investigation was to increase the coordination flexibility of the tetraacid linker and explore the accessibility of porous MOFs. Given that the carboxylate functionalities exhibit variable coordination modes, our goals were to access MOFs of the flexible H  4  L linker with different metal ions, and investigate the possibility of formation of MOFs that are isomeric or compositionally distinct, as in our earlier study. As evident from foregoing descriptions, we were successful in obtaining four different MOFs of the 4-connecting linker H  4  L. The four MOFs are Cd-MOF, Mn-MOF, and two concomitant Zn-MOFs with varying compositions of the linker and Zn2+ ions. Structure determinations of the otherwise limited number of MOFs demonstrate the fact that the unique D 2d -symmetry extant to the H  4  L linker allows, in first place, access to MOFs with high solvent-accessible volumes, which vary in the range of 43-52%. Clearly, the linker topology is decisive in controlling the porosity.

elements.content: An incisive analysis of the observed crystal structures permits following insights concerning the structural aspects of MOFs based on the attributes of the organic linker. First, with the exception of one instance in which the metal ion is found in a discrete environment, the metal ions are found to exist either as clusters or as 1D chains in all others. This attests to the fact that the ligands with increased flexibility dictate the occurrence of metal ions as clusters or chains, Further, literature survey reveals that the Zn-carboxylate SBUs formed with the linker H 4 L are unusual and not common. Second, the increased flexibility of the ligand leads to widely distinct topologies of the MOFs with different metal ions. It turns out that the topology observed for the Cd-MOF is heretofore unprecedented. The formation of two different types of MOFs with different compositions concomitantly in the same reaction vessel is a rare occurrence. As mentioned earlier, the reaction of H 4 L with Zn­(II) salt at 90 °C gives rise to two different forms, referred to as Zn-Lsqc and Zn-Ldia. Quite remarkably, temperature dependence of the formation of concomitant MOFs revealed that one observes the formation of Zn-Ldia exclusively at 110 °C, which suggests that the latter corresponds to the thermodynamic form of the two MOFs. Also, it was found that the crystals of Zn-Ldia can likewise be engineered, but by the additives such as 4,4′-bipyridyl. The finding that the bipyridyl additive leads to one of the MOFs exclusively was a result of chance/serendipity. The initial motivation, at the outset, was to access MOFs based on mixed organic linkers. The occurrence of this phenomenon, namely, concomitant formation of MOFs that are compositionally distinct, is rare and points to the choice of the linker in adopting two or more modes of self-assembly under identical conditions. In corroboration of previously documented results, the structural flexibility by virtue of acetic acid moieties at the periphery and some degree of torsional flexibility between the aryl rings that make up the core seemingly contribute to the observed concomitant formation of MOFs in addition to the unique topologies of MOFs and the occurrence of multimetal ion clusters and 1D chains of metals ions as SBUs. In are collected the values of the torsion angles observed between the planes of dimethoxyaryl rings (ϕs) and those between the aryl rings and the cetral dimethoxyaryl rings (Ψs) in all the structures of MOFs. The torsion angles clearly show that the angle between the central dimethoxybenzene rings lies between 75.7° and 88.5°. Similarly, the angle made by the peripheral aryl ring with respect to the central core varies in the range of 40.6–60.7°. Clearly, substantial torsional flexibility prevails between the aromatic planes of H 4 L.

Torsional Angles of the Linker <bold>L</bold> in the Resultant MOFs

Torsional angles between the aryl rings of the central core.

Torsional angles between the peripheral aromatic planes and the central core.

The bulk purities of all of the MOFs were established by comparing the powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the as-synthesized samples with the simulated profiles, obtained based on single crystal structure determinations (Figures S2 and S3). All of these MOFs are found to be quite stable in air. However, our attempts to remove the solvent molecules to create the guest-evacuated MOFs were unsuccessful, as the crystallinity was lost as confirmed from the PXRD patterns of the desolvated samples. This precluded our efforts to investigate their gas sorption properties. Interestingly, the desolvated materials in all the three MOFs, with the exception of Mn-L, were found to regain the crystallinity upon soaking the crystals in DMF again for few days.

However, our attempts to remove the solvent molecules to create the guest-evacuated MOFs were unsuccessful, as the crystallinity was lost as confirmed from the PXRD patterns of the desolvated samples. This precluded our efforts to investigate their gas sorption properties. Interestingly, the desolvated materials in all the three MOFs, with the exception of Mn-L, were found to regain the crystallinity upon soaking the crystals in DMF again for few days.

elements.content: A tetraacid organic linker H 4 L with peripheral flexibility introduced by (α-carboxy)­methoxy groups was designed and synthesized based on a twisted 2,2′,6,6′-tetra­meth­oxy­biphenyl scaffold for metal-assisted self-assembly with an objective to access MOFs and investigate how increased flexibility of the linker influences MOF topologies and their formation. While ortho-methoxy substituents in the biaryl core render the aromatic planes twisted, the (α-car­boxy)­methoxy-substituted phenyl rings endow the linker with palpable torsional flexibility to facilitate geometries necessary for metal–ligand coordination polymerization. Accordingly, the semi-rigid linker H 4 L lends itself to the formation of novel MOFs with interesting structural features. Reaction of H 4 L with cadmium, manganese, and zinc metal ions yielded four MOFs in which the metal ions form unusual inorganic SBUs. In Cd-L, the metal ions exhibit unusual coordination modes, leading to a 3D network with unprecedented topology. In Mn-L, one observes a 3,8-connecting network related to sqc-495 topology; the frameworks in both MOFs are noninterpenetrated. Unusual concomitant formation of compositionally distinct MOFs is observed when the linker is treated with ZnI2. Remarkably, both MOFs could be exclusively synthesized by varying experimental conditions involving temperature and additives. Both Zn-MOFs display considerable solvent-accessible volumes. The structural diversity observed in terms of the MOFs with limited metal ions using the linker H 4 L sufficiently emphasizes the importance of structural attributes of the linker in the formation of 3D porous MOFs decisively. In corroboration of our previous results, it emerges that the flexibility built into the structure of the organic linker, both at the central core and at the periphery, leads to concomitant formation of compositionally distinct MOFs in addition to diverse SBUs and disparate framework topologies. Although the crystals were found to collapse upon desolvation, they were found to be regenerated, with the exception of the crystals of Mn-MOF, upon resolvation with DMF.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A tetraacid organic linker H  4  L with peripheral flexibility introduced by (α-carboxy)methoxy groups was designed and synthesized based on a twisted 2,2',6,6'-tetramethoxybiphenyl scaffold for metal-assisted self-assembly with an objective to access MOFs and investigate how increased flexibility of the linker influences MOF topologies and their formation. While ortho-methoxy substituents in the biaryl core render the aromatic planes twisted, the (α-carboxy)methoxy-substituted phenyl rings endow the linker with palpable torsional flexibility to facilitate geometries necessary for metal-ligand coordination polymerization. Accordingly, the semi-rigid linker H  4  L lends itself to the formation of novel MOFs with interesting structural features. Reaction of H  4  L with cadmium, manganese, and zinc metal ions yielded four MOFs in which the metal ions form unusual inorganic SBUs. In Cd-L, the metal ions exhibit unusual coordination modes, leading to a 3D network with unprecedented topology. In Mn-L, one observes a 3,8-connecting network related to sqc-495 topology; the frameworks in both MOFs are noninterpenetrated. Unusual concomitant formation of compositionally distinct MOFs is observed when the linker is treated with ZnI2. Remarkably, both MOFs could be exclusively synthesized by varying experimental conditions involving temperature and additives. Both Zn-MOFs display considerable solvent-accessible volumes. The structural diversity observed in terms of the MOFs with limited metal ions using the linker H  4  L sufficiently emphasizes the importance of structural attributes of the linker in the formation of 3D porous MOFs decisively. In corroboration of our previous results, it emerges that the flexibility built into the structure of the organic linker, both at the central core and at the periphery, leads to concomitant formation of compositionally distinct MOFs in addition to diverse SBUs and disparate framework topologies. Although the crystals were found to collapse upon desolvation, they were found to be regenerated, with the exception of the crystals of Mn-MOF, upon resolvation with DMF.

The melting points were determined with a JSGW melting point apparatus. Column chromatography was conducted with silica-gel of 100–200 μ mesh (Souvenier Chemicals, India). elements.content: The tetraacid H 4 L (0.01 g, 0.011 mmol) and ZnI2 (0.0146 g, 0.044 mmol) were dissolved in 1.5 mL of DMF contained in a screw-capped vial. The vials were placed in a sand bath and heated at 90 °C for 2 days. The resultant mixture was allowed to cool down to rt slowly. Two different types of crystals, referred to subsequently as Zn-Lsqc and Zn-Ldia, were found to form concomitantly. The two types of crystals were separated manually and washed thoroughly with DMF to get rid of the adherent inorganic and organic components. The crystals were air-dried prior to use, yield 0.0082 g (70.8%) for Zn-Ldia and 0.0035 g (29.4%) for Zn-Lsqc.

elements.content: A good quality crystal in each case was chosen, mounted on a glass capillary, and the intensity data were collected at 100 K on a Bruker Nonius SMART APEX CCD diffractometer with a Mo-sealed Siemens ceramic diffraction tube (λ = 0.71073) and a highly oriented graphite monochromator. The data were processed with Bruker SAINTPLUS. Empirical absorption correction was made using the Bruker SADABS program. The structures were solved by using the SHELXTL package and refined by full matrix least-squares method based on F 2 using the SHELX97 program. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located from the difference Fourier, and those that could not be found were fixed in their ideal positions. They were assigned fixed isotropic U values and allowed to ride with their respective non-hydrogen atoms.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystal Structure Determinations

A good quality crystal in each case was chosen, mounted on a glass capillary, and the intensity data were collected at 100 K on a Bruker Nonius SMART APEX CCD diffractometer with a Mo-sealed Siemens ceramic diffraction tube (λ = 0.71073) and a highly oriented graphite monochromator. The data were processed with Bruker SAINTPLUS. Empirical absorption correction was made using the Bruker SADABS program. The structures were solved by using the SHELXTL package and refined by full matrix least-squares method based on F 2 using the SHELX97 program. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located from the difference Fourier, and those that could not be found were fixed in their ideal positions. They were assigned fixed isotropic U values and allowed to ride with their respective non-hydrogen atoms.

The tetraester, i.e., 3,3′,5,5′-tetra­kis­(4-(α-carbo­ethoxy)­meth­oxy-phenyl)-2,2′,6,6′-tetra­meth­oxy-1,1′-biphenyl, (2.0 g, 2.03 mmol), was dispersed in methanol containing K2CO3 (3.36 g, 24.36 mmol), and the resulting mixture was stirred at rt for 24 h. This procedure allowed precipitation of the tetraacid H 4 L3, which was collected by filtration after washing thoroughly with water and drying under high vacuum, yield 1.63g (92%); mp 194–196 °C; IR (KBr) cm–1 3460, 2938, 1726, 1608, 1511, 1464, 1404, 1220; 1H NMR (CD3OD, 500 MHz) δ 3.33 (s, 12H), 4.68 (s, 8H), 7.00 (d, J = 8.5, 8H), 7.31 (s, 2H), 7.53 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 8H); 13C NMR (CD3OD, 500 MHz) δ 60.6, 66.1, 115.6, 125.8, 131.2, 131.6, 133.06, 133.1, 156.5, 158.7, 173.0; ESI-MS– m/z [M – H]− Calcd for C48H41O16 873.2395, found 783.2395.

Synthesis of MOFs <bold>Cd-L</bold>

The tetraacid H 4 L (0.01 g, 0.011 mmol) and CdCl2·2H2O (0.0832 g, 0.044 mmol) were taken in a 5 mL screw-capped vial and dissolved in 2 mL of DMF by sonicating for 5 min. The reaction mixture was heated at 115 °C in a sand bath for 3 days. At the end of this period, the reaction mixture was allowed to cool down to rt very slowly. Colorless crystals of Cd-L formed were collected by filtration and washed with DMF thoroughly. The crystals were allowed to air-dry prior to use, yield 0.0065 g (51.2%).

<bold>Mn-L</bold>

H 4 L (0.01 g, 0.011 mmol) and MnCl2 (0.0575 g, 0.044 mmol) were dissolved in 2 mL of DMF contained in a 5 mL screw-capped vial. The solution was heated at 120 °C in a sand bath for 2 days. Slow cooling to the rt led to the formation of colorless crystals of Mn-L. The crystals were collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with DMF, and allowed to air-dry prior to use, yield 0.0052 g (37.7%).

<bold>Zn-Lsqc</bold> and <bold>Zn-Ldia</bold>

The tetraacid H 4 L (0.01 g, 0.011 mmol) and ZnI2 (0.0146 g, 0.044 mmol) were dissolved in 1.5 mL of DMF contained in a screw-capped vial. The vials were placed in a sand bath and heated at 90 °C for 2 days. The resultant mixture was allowed to cool down to rt slowly. Two different types of crystals, referred to subsequently as Zn-Lsqc and Zn-Ldia, were found to form concomitantly. The two types of crystals were separated manually and washed thoroughly with DMF to get rid of the adherent inorganic and organic components. The crystals were air-dried prior to use, yield 0.0082 g (70.8%) for Zn-Ldia and 0.0035 g (29.4%) for Zn-Lsqc.

Synthesis of 3,3',5,5'-Tetrakis(4-tert-butyldimethylsilyloxyphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetramethoxy-1,1'-biphenyl

To a degassed mixture of 30 mL of dioxane and water (1:1, v/v) taken in a two-neck round-bottom flask were added 3,3',5,5'-tetraiodo-2,2',6,6'-tetramethoxybiphenyl (2.0 g, 2.57 mmol), 4-(tert-butyldimethylsilyloxy)phenyl boronic acid (6.48 g, 25.7 mmol), sodium carbonate (2.72 g, 25.7 mmol), followed by Pd(PPh3)4 (0.89 g, 1.17 mmol), under a nitrogen gas atmosphere. The contents were heated at reflux for 48 h. At the end of this period, dioxane was removed in vacuo, and the organic matter was extracted with chloroform three times. The combined organic extract was dried over anhyd Na2SO4 and the solvent was removed in vacuo to get hold of the crude product. The latter was purified by silica gel column chromatography to afford the pure product as a colorless solid, yield 2.04 g (72%); mp 226-228 °C; IR (KBr) cm-1 3440, 2957, 2931, 2858, 1608, 1510, 1464, 1419, 1402; 1H NMR (CDCl3, 500 MHz) δ 0.22 (s, 24H), 1.0 (s, 36H), 3.34(s, 12H), 6.88 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 8H), 7.36 (s, 2H), 7.49 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 8H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 125 MHz) δ 18.2, 25.7, 60.1, 119.8, 129.9, 130.0, 131.8, 131.9, 154.6; ESI-MS+ m/z [M + NH4]+ Calcd for C64H94NO8Si4 1116.6057, found 1116.6051.

Synthesis of 3,3',5,5'-Tetrakis(4-hydroxyphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetramethoxy-1,1'-biphenyl

To a solution of 3,3',5,5'-tetrakis(4-tert-butyldimethylsilyloxyphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetramethoxy-1,1'-biphenyl (2.0 g, 1.82 mmol) in 20 mL of dry THF was added a solution of 8.2 mL of 1 M TBAF in THF (8.2 mmol) dropwise over a period of 10 min under a nitrogen atmosphere. The reaction mixture was allowed to stir overnight and quenched subsequently with ice. THF was removed in vacuo and the product was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with water, and allowed to dry to obtain tetraphenol product as a white solid in almost quantitative yield, 1.16 g (1.8 mmol); mp 258-260 °C; IR (KBr) cm-1 3288, 2940, 1612, 1591, 1514, 1465, 1411, 1221; 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 500 MHz) δ 3.25 (s, 12H), 6.82 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 8H), 7.24 (s, 2H), 7.42 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 8H); 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6, 125 MHz) δ 59.6, 115.3, 124.2, 128.6, 129.7, 129.9, 131.3, 154.3, 156.6; ESI-MS+ m/z [M + NH4]+ Calcd for C40H38NO8 660.2597, found 660.2595.

Synthesis of 3,3',5,5'-Tetrakis(4-(α-carboethoxy)methoxyphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetramethoxy-1,1'-biphenyl

To a solution of the tetraphenol (2.0 g, 3.11 mmol), isolated above, in dry acetonitrile (40 mL) contained in a two-neck round-bottom flask were added K2CO3 (4.3 g, 31.15 mmol), BrCH2CO2Et (3.4 mL, 31.15 mmol), and a catalytic amount of 18-crown-6 (0.04 g, 0.16 mmol). The resultant mixture was heated at reflux for 48 h. Progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC analysis. After the reaction was judged to be complete, THF was removed in vacuo and the reaction mixture was extracted with EtOAc/water three times. The combined organic layer was dried over anhyd Na2SO4 and the solvent was removed under vacuum to afford the tetraester as a crude product. The latter was purified by silica gel column chromatography to get hold of the pure product as an off-white solid, yield 2.49 g (81%); mp 108-110 °C; IR (KBr) cm-1 3435, 2981, 2938, 1760, 1730, 1608, 1557, 1512, 1463, 1405; 1H NMR (CDCl3, 500 MHz) δ 1.31 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 12H), 3.35 (s, 12H), 4.29 (q, J = 6.9 Hz, 8H), 4.66 (s, 8H), 6.95 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 8H), 7.34 (s, 2H), 7.55 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 8H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 125 MHz) δ 14.2, 60.3, 61.4, 65.5, 114.5, 124.2, 129.7, 130.2, 132.0, 132.2, 155.3, 156.9, 169.0; ESI-MS+ m/z [M + NH4]+ Calcd for C56H62NO16 1004.4069, found 1004.4067.

Synthesis of 3,3',5,5'-Tetrakis(4-(α-carboxy)methoxyphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetramethoxy-1,1'-biphenyl, H4L 

The tetraester, i.e., 3,3',5,5'-tetrakis(4-(α-carboethoxy)methoxy-phenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetramethoxy-1,1'-biphenyl, (2.0 g, 2.03 mmol), was dispersed in methanol containing K2CO3 (3.36 g, 24.36 mmol), and the resulting mixture was stirred at rt for 24 h. At the end of the reaction, methanol was removed in vacuo, the solid residue was dissolved in a minimum amount of water and acidified with conc. HCl. This procedure allowed precipitation of the tetraacid H  4  L3, which was collected by filtration after washing thoroughly with water and drying under high vacuum, yield 1.63g (92%); mp 194-196 °C; IR (KBr) cm-1 3460, 2938, 1726, 1608, 1511, 1464, 1404, 1220; 1H NMR (CD3OD, 500 MHz) δ 3.33 (s, 12H), 4.68 (s, 8H), 7.00 (d, J = 8.5, 8H), 7.31 (s, 2H), 7.53 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 8H); 13C NMR (CD3OD, 500 MHz) δ 60.6, 66.1, 115.6, 125.8, 131.2, 131.6, 133.06, 133.1, 156.5, 158.7, 173.0; ESI-MS- m/z [M - H]- Calcd for C48H41O16 873.2395, found 783.2395.

The tetraacid H  4  L (0.01 g, 0.011 mmol) and CdCl2⋅2H2O (0.0832 g, 0.044 mmol) were taken in a 5 mL screw-capped vial and dissolved in 2 mL of DMF by sonicating for 5 min. Colorless crystals of Cd-L formed were collected by filtration and washed with DMF thoroughly. The crystals were allowed to air-dry prior to use, yield 0.0065 g (51.2%).

 H  4  L (0.01 g, 0.011 mmol) and MnCl2 (0.0575 g, 0.044 mmol) were dissolved in 2 mL of DMF contained in a 5 mL screw-capped vial. The solution was heated at 120 °C in a sand bath for 2 days. Slow cooling to the rt led to the formation of colorless crystals of Mn-L. The crystals were collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with DMF, and allowed to air-dry prior to use, yield 0.0052 g (37.7%).

The tetraacid H  4  L (0.01 g, 0.011 mmol) and ZnI2 (0.0146 g, 0.044 mmol) were dissolved in 1.5 mL of DMF contained in a screw-capped vial.
